## Introduction

The data for this analysis comes from the World Development Indicators database [@worldbank_wdi_2022].

### Loading
```{python}
#| label: load-data
#| echo: true

import pandas as pd

wdi = pd.read_csv('wdi.csv')

wdi.head()

#| label: setup
#| include: false

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

sns.set_style("whitegrid")
```


### Life Expectancy analysis:
```{python}
life_exp_series = wdi['life_expectancy']
print("Life Expectancy (Years):")
print(f"- Mean: {life_exp_series.mean():.2f}")
print(f"- Median: {life_exp_series.median():.2f}")
print(f"- Standard Deviation: {life_exp_series.std():.2f}")
```

```{python}
#| label: fig-life-exp-dist
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "Distribution of Life Expectancy in 2022."

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.histplot(life_exp_series, kde=True, bins=30, color='green')
plt.title('Distribution of Life Expectancy (2022)')
plt.xlabel('Life Expectancy at Birth (Years)')
plt.ylabel('Number of Countries')
plt.show()
```

From the summary statistics in **@tbl-summary**, we see that the mean life expectancy of the countries is 72.42, the median is 73.51, and the standard deviation is 7.71. In **@fig-life-exp-dist**, we see a longer and thiner tail of life expectancies on the lower end, and a shorter and thicker tail of life expectancies on the high end. In developmental economics, the Preston Curve tells us that life expectancy does not have a linear relationship to GDP per capita [@preston_1975].

### Inflation analysis:
```{python}
inf_rate_series = wdi['inflation_rate']
print("Inflation Rate (Annual %):")
print(f"- Mean: {inf_rate_series.mean():.2f}")
print(f"- Median: {inf_rate_series.median():.2f}")
print(f"- Standard Deviation: {inf_rate_series.std():.2f}")
```
```{python}

#| label: fig-inflation-swarm
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "A swarm plot of 2022 inflation rates, showing the precise location of each country."

plt.figure(figsize=(12, 4))

# Create the horizontal swarm plot
sns.swarmplot(x=wdi['inflation_rate'], color='purple', size=4)

# Improve readability
plt.title('Distribution of Inflation Rate (2022)')
plt.xlabel('Inflation, Consumer Prices (Annual %)')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

From the summary statistics in **@tbl-summary**, we see that the mean inflation rate is 12.49 percent, the median is 7.97 percent, and the standard deviation is 19.68 percent. In **@fig-inflation-swarm**, we see a vaguely normal distribution. Most of the data points are clustered between 0 and 20 percent annual inflation, with a few outliers on the right tail. Economists have found that outlier inflation has adverse economic effects [@barro_1996].

### GDP Per Capita analysis:
```{python}
gdp_series = wdi['gdp_per_capita']
print("GDP Per Capita (USD):")
print(f"- Mean: ${gdp_series.mean():,.2f}")
print(f"- Median: ${gdp_series.median():,.2f}")
print(f"- Standard Deviation: ${gdp_series.std():,.2f}")
```
```{python}
#| label: fig-gdp-dist
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "Distribution of GDP Per Capita in 2022."

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.histplot(gdp_series, kde=True, bins=30)
plt.title('Distribution of GDP Per Capita (2022)')
plt.xlabel('GDP Per Capita (Current USD)')
plt.ylabel('Number of Countries')
plt.show()
```

From the summary statistics in **@tbl-summary**, we see that the mean GDP per capita of the countries is $20,345.71, the median is $7,587.59, and standard deviation is $31,308.94. In **@fig-gdp-dist**, we observe that the GDP per capita of the countries in the data set follow a power law distributions. Most of the countries are clustered in the low GDP per capita buckets, a small number a clustered in middle GDP per capita buckets, and there are a tiny number of outliers with very high GDP per capita. 

```{python}
#| label: tbl-summary
#| tbl-cap: "Summary Statistics for Key Indicators (2022)."
#| results: asis
#| echo: false

indicators = {
    'gdp_per_capita': 'GDP per Capita ($)',
    'life_expectancy': 'Life Expectancy (Years)',
    'inflation_rate': 'Inflation Rate (%)'
}
stats_to_calc = ['mean', 'median', 'std']

summary_data = {}
for indicator_code, indicator_name in indicators.items():
    summary_data[indicator_name] = [
        wdi[indicator_code].mean(),
        wdi[indicator_code].median(),
        wdi[indicator_code].std()
    ]

summary_df = pd.DataFrame(
    summary_data,
    index=['Mean', 'Median', 'Standard Deviation']
)

print(summary_df.to_markdown(floatfmt=",.2f"))
```
